doc.title: Latam Equity Quant
doc.source_uri: 2025-08-29/A week of record highsA week of record highs_2025-08-29

passages.text: Key takeaways- LatAm markets reached record highs this week. Ibovespa outperformed LatAm and global markets.- We continue to see outflows from Brazil equity funds, but it is slowing down. Last week we saw R\\(0.8bn in outflows.- B3 announced its last Ibov preview. As expected, C&A and Curry will be included, while Sao Martinho and Petz were removed.

Performance of the week (USD total returns): Ibovespa \(+2.6\%\) vs Mexico \(- 0.4\%\) SPX \(+0.5\%\) EM- \(0.4\%\) . Many LatAm markets reached record highs this week. Yesterday, Ibovespa reached 142k (intraday) and IPSA (Chile) reached 8.9k. BLV (Peru) reached 34.6k on \(26^{\mathrm{th}}\) , IPSA (Chile). Last week on Aug \(22^{\mathrm{nd}}\) , Colcap (Colombia) reached new time highs at 1.9k and Mexico touched 59k. The S&P500 also reached new highs on Aug \(28^{\mathrm{th}}\) .

LatAm markets rallied YTD \((+32\%)\) , USD total return) as well as many emergent markets mainly given depressed valuations and currencies last year (see our thematic: LatAm thrives in EM comeback). In fact, MSCI EM reached its highest point since Feb- 21 (and if we consider total returns, it would also be at all- time highs this week).

Valuation update in LatAm after 2025 rally: Brazil (ex- commodities) trading at only \(7\%\) discount vs historicals (12m fwd P/E), Chile trading at an \(11\%\) discount, Mexico trading at a \(15\%\) discount, Peru trading at a \(21\%\) discount and Colombia trading at a \(34\%\) discount (see our valuation table in Exhibit 7).
US\\$0.9bn outflows from EM (ex- China and Taiwan) funds this week. YTD, these funds had US\\$19bn inflows, which compares to US\\$23bn outflows in 2024 (Exhibit 15).

Outflows from local equity funds in Brazil slowing down. R\\(0.8bn outflows from Brazil local equity funds. In the first half of 2025, we saw R\)1.3bn outflows from BZ equity funds on average. See Exhibit 9. Almost all inflows that BZ equity funds received from 2018 to 2021 (close to R\)23.0bn inflows), were drained since Sep- 2021 (close to - R\\$220bn, see Exhibit 8).

Ibovespa preview: Yesterday, B3 announced its final official preview for the Ibovespa index. Changes will be effective Monday, Sep 1st. B3 announced that C&A Modas (CEAB3) will be included, and Petz (PETZ3) will be removed. Curry (CURY3) will also be included, and Sao Martinho (SMTO3) will be removed, as was previously announced in the 2nd preview.

Trading ideas and investment strategies discussed herein may give rise to significant risk and are not suitable for all investors. Investors should have experience in relevant markets and the financial resources to absorb any losses arising from applying these ideas or strategies.
Refer to "Other Important Disclosures" for information on certain BofA Securities entities that take responsibility for the information herein in particular jurisdictions.

BofA Securities does and seeks to do business with issuers covered in its research reports. As a result, investors should be aware that the firm may have a conflict of interest that could affect the objectivity of this report. Investors should consider this report as only a single factor in making their investment decision. Refer to important disclosures on page 15 to 17.
Investment Strategy Latin America

The Earnings Revision Ratio measures the number of revisions for which the consensus EPS estimate has risen versus the number for which it has fallen.

An ERR above 1 means more upwards revisions than downwards revisions. However, historically analysts tend to start overly optimistic and do more downwards revisions down the line. As a result, the overall historical average of the 3- month ERR is close to 0.8
Exhibit 22: LatAm 3-month ERR below 1.0 YTD. LatAm Earnings Revision Ratio

The Earnings Revision Ratio (ERR) is calculated as follows: ERR = #Up Revisions / #Down Revisions, where:

We look at 1- Month and 3- Month ERRs; the former may anticipate market turns, while the latter is less volatile. Each company may contribute more than once as the total number of analyst revisions are considered. A company covered by several analysts will have a higher weight in the ratio.

The considered universe is composed of all companies within our current LatAm Coverage countries (Argentina, Brazil, Chile, Colombia, Mexico and Peru). A company will be included in the sample if at least one of the following variables is listed as one of said countries: country of risk, country of incorporation, country of registration, country of Headquarters, and country of top revenue. Panama's Copa Holdings is the only exception to the rule and was also added to the sample.
Exhibit 27: Financials has the highest ERR in Mexico (1.0). Mexico 3-month ERR - sector details

Stock screens methodologyOur monthly screens are a quantitative approach for monitoring performance across several investment strategies. The screens are generated through a quantitative process, using consensus projections and historical data. There are two main steps to the selection process: filtering and ranking. For each screening process, filter criteria is applied first, then resulting assets are ranked according to the core variable for each strategy. Each month, we select and rank the 20 stocks that best fit the screen criteria. The stocks are selected from our universe of coverage in LatAm regardless of the rating but must have a market cap above US\$1bn.

There are 5 different screens: Growth, Value, Dividends, Defensive and High Beta. Our Growth screen looks for companies with high projected growth that reinvests free cash flow. Our Value screen looks for companies with low or moderate leverage that are trading at a discounted valuation. The Dividends screen looks for companies with high dividend yields, supported by low moderate leverage. Defensive screen looks for assets with solid performance and lowest volatility while High beta screen looks for market- dependent assets with high leverage and volatility. We also provide a list of stocks within our coverage that are most discounted to historicals.

The date and time of completion of the production of any recommendation in this report shall be the date and time of dissemination of this report as recorded in the report timestamp.
